## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 339, 415, 375]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 767, 545]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 760, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 730, 89]]<|/det|> A student determines the weight of a metre rule using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 369, 120]]<|/det|> Fig. 1.1. shows the apparatus. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 129, 897, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 288, 532, 307]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 146, 338]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 320, 579, 338]]<|/det|> The student places the metre rule on the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 351, 191, 368]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 351, 811, 368]]<|/det|> He places the load \(\mathbf{P}\), labelled \(\mathbf{1.5N}\), on the metre rule at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 381, 175, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 920, 415]]<|/det|> Keeping \(\mathbf{P}\) at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark, he adjusts the position of the metre rule on the pivot so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 428, 178, 446]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 428, 801, 446]]<|/det|> In Table 1.1, he records the distance \(a\) from the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 460, 180, 478]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 460, 920, 494]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) between the centre of load \(\mathbf{P}\) and the pivot. [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 505, 178, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 544, 523]]<|/det|> Calculate \(\frac{a}{b}\). Record its value in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 918, 523]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 146, 554]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 535, 920, 570]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure using loads of 1.2N, 1.0N, 0.8N and 0.5N. The readings and results are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 583, 541, 600]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 610, 740, 777]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the time taken for metal balls to stop moving after being released on a curved track. Fig. 4.1 shows the shape of the track. The track is flexible, so the shape of the curve can be changed.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 175, 787, 308]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 420, 396]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 485, 427]]<|/det|>
a selection of metal balls of different masses

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 256, 441]]<|/det|>
the flexible track

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 442, 317, 457]]<|/det|>
clamps to hold the track

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 458, 220, 473]]<|/det|>
a stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 473, 250, 488]]<|/det|>
a tape measure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 489, 220, 504]]<|/det|>
a metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
The student can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 920, 599]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate a factor that affects the time taken for metal balls to stop moving after being released on a curved track.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 613, 324, 630]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 644, 536, 660]]<|/det|>
· state how you would expect the balls to move

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 562, 691]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 705, 855, 722]]<|/det|>
· state which variables you would keep constant and which variable you would change

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 736, 920, 769]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 784, 683, 800]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 663, 89]]<|/det|>
You may add to the diagram in Fig. 4.1 if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]
